Authors:
OLIUL HASSAN, Ju Sung Kim, Bekale Be Ndong Dimitri Romain,
Taehyun Chang
Title:
Investigation of Diversity and pathogenicity of
Colletotrichum species causing Ovate-leaf Atractylodes Anthracnose in
South Korea and description of a new species, Colletotrichum ovataense
sp. nov.
Keywords:
Colletotrichum species, multilocus phylogenetic analyses,
pathogenicity test, Atractylodes ovata
Abstract:
Ovate-leaf Atractylodes (Atractylodes ovata) is the
well-known medicinal plant in Korea. Dried rhizome and the root extract
are used for making herbal medicine. Anthracnose is the great challenge
to Ovate-leaf Atractylodes (OLA) cultivation in South Korea.
Colletotrichum spp. is the major group of plant pathogen and responsible
for anthracnose on a range of economically important hosts, but
occurrence of this pathogen on Ovate-leaf Atractylodes remain
unresolved. To investigate the diversity, morphology, phylogeny and
biology of Colletotrichum spp. 32 fungal isolates were obtained form 30
OLA affected leaves from five farmers field in two cultivation regions
(Mungyeong and Sangju) of South Korea. Phylogenetic analysis with four/
five gene loci (ITS, TUB2, ACT, GAPDH, and / CHS-1,) along with
morphology of 26 representative isolates delineated six previously known
Colletotrichum species including C. fructicola, C. gloeosporioides s.s.,
C. kahawae, C. plurivorum, C. siamense and C. sojae, and one new species
illustrated here as C. ovataense. Among these species, C.
gloeosporioides s.s. and C. plurivorum was the highly prevalent species.
Pathogenicity test on detached leaves to confirm KochÂ’s postulates
revealed that identified Colletotrichum species different degree of
virulence. In this study, C. fructicola, C. kahawae, C. plurivorum, C.
siamense and C. sojae were reported for the first time as the causal
agent of Ovate-leaf Atractylodes anthracnose. Understanding the
diversity and biology of the Colletotrichum species population will help
in disease management.
